puṭṭhumakāmamāgamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound functioning as a descriptive phrase, likely modifying a noun in the omitted sentence. It describes an approach or arrival without any inclination or desire to question or inquire.

pārāyananteva.meaning_2: just as the final aim; only as the chief object
pārāyananteva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an adverbial sandhi form functioning as an indeclinable expression, combining the instrumental singular of pārāyana ('pārāyanantena') with eva ('just, only'), meaning 'just as the final aim' or 'only as the way to the beyond'. It likely emphasizes the Pārāyana chapter of the Sutta Nipāta in a contextual sentence, though no sentence is provided.

mānamakkhappahāyino.meaning_2: abandoning pride and conceit; giving up egotism and denigration
mānamakkhappahāyino.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound functioning as a descriptive adjective for those who have abandoned pride (māna) and conceit or denigration (makkha). The form -pahāyino is nominative plural masculine of the adjective pahāyī derived from pajahati.

tamanudāsino.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adjective formed from 'tamanuda' (dispeller of darkness) and 'āsina' (seated, past participle of āsati), likely meaning 'one seated as a dispeller of darkness' or metaphorically 'calm and free from mental darkness'. Without the full sentence context, the precise usage is inferred from the components.

saṃkappayantāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form saṃkappayantāya is the instrumental singular of the present participle, used to denote 'by one who is thinking' or 'by the one forming thoughts'. No contextual sentence provided, but typically in Pāli texts, it describes mental activity or intention in Buddhist contexts.
